title: New Zealand vs South Africa, Rugby World Cup 2019 LIVE: Stream, UK kick-off time, news
text:
Follow live updates from the Rugby World Cup as New Zealand and South Africa go head to head this morning at Yokohama’s Nissan Stadium.

As one of the game’s fiercest rivalries, it’s a match that promises to be jam-packed with drama and world-class rugby, with both teams set to hold nothing back as they target a top-placed finish in Pool B.

Their last meeting at the Rugby World Cup came in 2015, with eventual winners New Zealand beating their rivals 20-18 in a tense semi-final at Twickenham. Follow all the action below:

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

New Zealand vs South Africa team news New Zealand starting XV: Beauden Barrett, Sevu Reece, Anton Lienert-Brown, Ryan Crotty, George Bridge, Richie Mo’unga, Aaron Smith, Kieran Read (captain), Sam Cane, Ardie Savea, Scott Barrett, Sam Whitelock, Nepu Laulala, Dane Coles, Joe Moody.

Beauden Barrett, Sevu Reece, Anton Lienert-Brown, Ryan Crotty, George Bridge, Richie Mo’unga, Aaron Smith, Kieran Read (captain), Sam Cane, Ardie Savea, Scott Barrett, Sam Whitelock, Nepu Laulala, Dane Coles, Joe Moody. South Africa starting XV: Willie Le Roux, Cheslin Kolbe, Lukhanyo Am, Damian de Allende, Makazole Mapimpi, Handré Pollard, Faf de Klerk; Duane Vermeulen, Pieter-Steph du Toit, Siya Kolisi (c), Franco Mostert, Eben Etzebeth, Frans Malherbe, Malcolm Marx, Steven Kitshoff.

20 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa The Springboks' spell of pressure is rewarded with another penalty... but he's missed! Pollard hits the post from 20 metres or so out. Can't be missing those... 18 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa Another scrum, another South Africa put-in. De Klerk zips it out to De Allende who goes crashing into a wall of black shirts. The forwards are on hand to quickly pick and drive, carrying play a good few metres forward. The process repeats, with South Africa gaining even more ground before eventually they pull the trigger and go for the dink over the top. Mo'unga mops up possession but he's carried over his own line. South Africa asking some probing questions here. 14 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa More pressure from the Springboks who are really beginning to dictate the flow of this match. They're pushing New Zealand back and back deep into their own 22. Hansen's men eventually get a hold of play before clearing their lines for another South African line-out. 11 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa The All Blacks are up the halfway line now and sense an opportunity... or they did until Crotty fumbled his pass, with the ball fortunately bouncing back to keep play alive. Moments later Barrett spots a gap in the South African line and attempts to make a break as he burns the furnace. He's almost makes it through before being brought down at the Springboks' second time of asking. Advertisement 9 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa That didn't take long. We have our first scuffle of the match, with a number of the forwards squaring up to one another down in the left-hand corner near South Africa's line. Handbags away, gents. 7 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa South Africa looking confident in these early encounters; they're taking the fight to their opponents with De Klerk keeping his backs busy with some quick hands and smart kicks over the top. 5 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa All Black line-out. Coles sends it long, really long. The intended target looked to be Reece but he couldn't quite get his hands to it and ended up knocking-on. The Springboks have the put-in at the scrum. 3 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa Wow. De Klerk, surely the smallest man on the pitch, hits Am with an absolute crunching tackle that sounds the All Black crumbling to the floor. The No 9 sure does pack a punch. Advertisement 1 min - New Zealand 0-3 South Africa Penalty already! South Africa are handed a kick at the sticks after a dangerous All Black clearance at the ruck. Pollard converts. The Springboks lead. With everything out of the way, there's only one thing left. Here we go folks - kick-off! And here's the Haka! The South African fans are doing their best to drown it but the All Blacks' voices can still be heard. This is spine-tingling stuff, with each roar from the men below drawing rapturous applause from the neutrals in the crowd. Right, that's that - party time. Advertisement The players are out! Time for the national anthems! Quite the view, quite the stadium. The final for the 2002 World Cup was held here, with Brazil famously claiming a 2-0 victory. You knew that already, though. 20 minutes to go until kick-off folks, with both teams currently going through some last-minute preparations on the pitch. The stadium is filling up nicely now, with the bright lights above adding to the awe and scale of the occasion. This should be a good one. There was a thrilling end to the clash between France and Argentina, with the French coming out on top by two points after a late penalty-kick miss from the Pumas. Catch up on all the reaction from that match here: France vs Argentina LIVE: Rugby World Cup latest updates Advertisement Hansen was having none of it, though, and accused his counterpart of trying to influence French referee Jérôme Garcès before today’s game. “Whilst I’ve got a lot of respect for South Africa and particularly Rassie, I don’t agree with what he’s doing. He’s trying to put pressure on referees externally and they’re under enough pressure already. They don’t need us coaches doing what he’s doing.”

What have the head coaches been saying then? As to be expected, there was that pre-match verbal spar between Erasmus and Hansen. The former doubled down down on a claim by one of his assistants that referees give New Zealand a slightly easier ride, and that there is a more level playing field now that the side has dropped to No 2 in the rankings. "Because New Zealand were No 1 in the world for so long… they had so much respect on every level, even from referees, and I think that's a well-known fact," he said. "In the tough times when teams were under the pump some of the 50-50 calls went their [All Blacks'] way. They deserved that for being No 1 for so long.”

So what about the Springboks? South Africa have a host of world-class players among their ranks, including Siya Kolisi, South Africa’s first ever black captain, and Wasps’ Willie le Roux. But it’s Faf de Klerk who could prove to be the difference in Japan. Described as a “little buzzsaw” by Eddie Jones, the nine has hit new heights since moving to Sale in 2017, with his energy, decision-making and wide-ranging set of skills a real asset to the Rassie Erasmus' side. How can I live stream it?

You can live stream the match via ITV Hub on a range of devices, including laptops, smartphones and tablets.

When is it?

New Zealand v South Africa kicks off at 10:45am (BST) on Saturday 21 September.

Team news

New Zealand starting XV: Beauden Barrett, Sevu Reece, Anton Lienert-Brown, Ryan Crotty, George Bridge, Richie Mo’unga, Aaron Smith, Kieran Read (captain), Sam Cane, Ardie Savea, Scott Barrett, Sam Whitelock, Nepu Laulala, Dane Coles, Joe Moody.

Replacements: Codie Taylor, Ofa Tuungafasi, Angus Ta’avao, Patrick Tuipulotu, Shannon Frizell, TJ Perenara, Sonny Bill Williams, Ben Smith.

South Africa starting XV: Willie Le Roux, Cheslin Kolbe, Lukhanyo Am, Damian de Allende, Makazole Mapimpi, Handré Pollard, Faf de Klerk; Duane Vermeulen, Pieter-Steph du Toit, Siya Kolisi (c), Franco Mostert, Eben Etzebeth, Frans Malherbe, Malcolm Marx, Steven Kitshoff.

Replacements: Mbongeni Mbonambi, Tendai Mtawarira, Trevor Nyakane, RG Snyman, Francois Louw, Herschel Jantjies, Francois Steyn, Jesse Kriel.
